evidence: In a recent report Wu et al. [12] demonstrated first room temperature tensile behavior of Hf 25 Nb 25 Ti 25 Zr 25 HEA. The homogenized alloy exhibited yield strength of about 879 MPa that was accompanied by a room temperature ductility of about 15%.

microstructure: The initial microstructure of the as-cast material shows a wide size distribution of randomly oriented grains, with very large grains (~ 600 microns) within the distribution of grain size. Unindexed areas in some grains are related to micro-segregation in the interdendritic zones.
evidence: The initial microstructure of the as-cast material is shown in Fig.  3  and was presented in previous works  [25, 26] . Figure  3a  shows an EBSD IPF map. It shows a wide size distribution of randomly oriented grains (see top left insert), which was also confirmed by the overall crystallographic texture measurements (pole figures) presented in Fig.  3b  (RD and TD labels have no special meaning here). However, a maximum intensity level of about 16 is noted which is most probably related to the presence of very large grains (~ 600 microns) within the distribution of grain size. Unindexed areas in some grains seen in Fig.  3b  (see the left side of the image) are related to micro-segregation in the interdendritic zones  [17] .

Interestingly, the above described mechanical characteristics are similar to that reported for refractory Ti 25 Hf 25 Zr 25 Nb 25 high entropy alloy by Wu et al  [12] . Indeed, the author reported that during plastic deformation dislocation tangles are formed and accumulate around grain boundaries and slip bands.

Room temperature tensile tests showed only remote micro-segregation effect of the mechanical behavior of the as-cast materials: depending on the specimen location, yield strengths at 0.002 offset in the range a 800 -840 MPa were obtained. The latter are within experimental error.
